chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation
sanskrit:
सिद्धिं प्राप्तो यथा ब्रह्म तथाप्नोति निबोध मे ।
समासेनैव कौन्तेय निष्ठा ज्ञानस्य या परा ॥५०॥
transliteration:
siddhiṁ prāpto yathā brahma tathāpnoti nibodha me |
samāsenaiva kaunteya niṣṭhā jñānasya yā parā ||50||
translation: Learn from Me, O son of Kunti, how one who has attained perfection reaches Brahman, that supreme state of knowledge, which I shall explain to you briefly.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna transitions to describing the culmination of spiritual practice - the attainment of Brahman realization. Having explained the path of action performed with proper understanding and detachment, Krishna now promises to teach Arjuna how one who has achieved perfection (siddhi) through such practice ultimately realizes Brahman, the Absolute Reality. The use of 'samāsena' (briefly) indicates that Krishna will provide a concise summary of this profound knowledge.

This verse serves as a bridge between the discussion of karma yoga and the description of jñāna niṣṭhā (steadfastness in knowledge) that follows. Krishna emphasizes that reaching Brahman is not merely theoretical knowledge but represents the highest culmination (parā niṣṭhā) of spiritual wisdom. The verse prepares Arjuna for the subsequent description of the qualities and practices of one established in transcendental knowledge, showing that perfection in action naturally leads to the realization of the Supreme.
speaker: Krishna
